thread.title: What Israel's West Bank settlement means for those on both sides of the conflict
thread.title_full: What Israel's West Bank settlement means for those on both sides of the conflict

author: Sophie McNeill
title: What Israel's West Bank settlement means for those on both sides of the conflict
text:
Dr Hagai Ben-Artzi stands on the top of the highest point in his settlement of Beit El and looks out over the West Bank. 
He is pleased by what he sees. 
"We have succeeded to bring almost 1 million Jews to Judea and Samaria and to East Jerusalem," he says, pointing out over hills. 
"And we hope that there will be a new page, a new era in the history of the settlements with President Trump!" 
This land is supposed to be the other half of the 'two-state solution', where one day a state of Palestine could exist next to Israel. 
But Israeli troops have now occupied this territory for 50 years and during that time hundreds of thousands of Israeli settlers have moved here to claim the land. Photo: Demountable buildings in the Israeli settlement of Beit El in the West Bank. (ABC News) 
"Judea and Samaria are the biblical and historical lands of the Jewish people," Dr Ben-Artzi says, using the biblical name for the West Bank. 
"Just open the Bible. It tells about the Jewish people coming 4,000 years ago. The Arabs only came about 1,000 years ago!" Infographic: Israeli settlements in the West Bank (UN OCHA) 
Dr Ben-Artzi hopes Donald Trump's election will bring a new era of settlement expansion will make it impossible for a Palestinian state to ever be created on this land. 
"We hope that in the time of Trump people will stop talking about that stupid and crazy idea of two sate solution which is absolutely impossible," he tells the ABC. 
"There's one state in the land of Israel and that's the state of Israel." 
For the people of Beit El, the election of Mr Trump is hugely exciting. 
Mr Trump's personal foundation has donated $10,000 to this settlement, while the man the US President has appointed to be America's Ambassador to Israel, David Friedman, chairs one of Beit El's biggest fundraising efforts in the US. 
"Mr Freidman is a friend of Beit El. He donated money to Beit El. He came to visit Beit El," Dr Ben-Artzi explains. 
"He is also a good friend of the settlement movement." 
For the past eight years, Barack Obama's opposition to settlements and the pressure his administration placed on the Israeli Government meant it was difficult to obtain building permits here. 
Now in Beit El, there's hope temporary housing will soon be replaced by a building boom. 
"People had to live in these caravan, trailers," Dr Ben-Artzi says, pointing at several rows of demountable buildings. 
"We hope that in the time of the new president, President Trump, they should be able to build normal houses." 'Hilltops confiscated by the settlers' Photo: Issa Amro, who runs the NGO Youth Against Settlements. (ABC News) 
For Palestinians, the expansion of Israeli settlements across the West Bank has had a daily impact on their lives. 
"Everywhere in the West Bank you find settlements and the settlements are completely restricting the movement of the Palestinians between their own cities and one town and another," says Issa Amro. 
A human rights activist from Hebron, Mr Amro runs the NGO Youth Against Settlements.
